raw_text:
Dominici backs lacklustre France
 
 Wing Christophe Dominici says France can claim another Six Nations Grand Slam despite two lacklustre wins so far against Scotland and England.
 
 The champions only just saw off the Scots in Paris, then needed England to self-destruct in last week's 18-17 win. "The English played better than us but lost, whereas we are still in the race for the Grand Slam," said Dominici. "We know our display was not perfect, but we can still win the Grand Slam, along with Ireland and Wales." France , Ireland and Wales all remain unbeaten after two rounds of this year's RBS Six Nations, with the two Celtic nations playing by far the more impressive rugby.
 
 France take on Wales at the Stade de France on 26 February and Ireland in Dublin on 12 March. But although France have yet to click, Dominici says that they can still win the hard way as long as scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili continues in his goalkicking form. "If we have an efficient kicker on whom we can rely on, a solid defence and a team who play for their lives, we can achieve something," Dominici added. "I said at the start of the competition that the winners would be clearer from the third matches, and that's exactly what is going to happen." France coach Bernard Laporte will announce his starting line-up next Tuesday for the match against Wales.
 
 Wing Jimmy Marlu is definitely out with the knee injury sustained at Twickenham, which is likely to sideline him for the rest of the tournament. Inspirational flanker Serge Betsen is a doubt with a thigh injury, but number eight Imanol Harinordoquy has shaken off his shoulder injury. In the backs, centre Yannick Jauzion and winger Aurelien Rougerie are all back in contention after injury, while Brive back Julien Laharrague has received his first call-up as a replacement for Pepito Elhorga.
llama3.2:1b: France will attempt to win their second Six Nations Grand Slam despite struggling with two lackluster wins so far.
Dominici says France can still win the tournament if they remain unbeaten and have a strong team performance.
They face Wales on 26 February, followed by Ireland in Dublin on 12 March.
llama3.2:3b: France can claim a Six Nations Grand Slam despite two lacklustre wins, says coach Christophe Dominici.
The team is unbeaten but "not perfect", with scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili being key to their success.
France face Wales on February 26 and Ireland on March 12, with injuries affecting several players including Jimmy Marlu and Serge Betsen.
gemma2:2b: Dominici believes France can still win the Six Nations Grand Slam despite two less than stellar victories against Scotland and England.
France remains in contention alongside Ireland and Wales, with both Celtic nations playing more convincingly so far.
Dominici emphasizes France's strength through a reliable kicker (Yachvili) and solid defense.
The team will face Wales at home on February 26th before a match against Ireland on March 12th.
Jimmy Marlu is out for the rest of the tournament, while Serge Betsen is injured.
Yannick Jauzion and Aurelien Rougerie are returning, and Julien Laharrague has been called up as a replacement.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Dominici backs France despite two poor performances against Scotland and England, with the team claiming another Six Nations Grand Slam by winning against Ireland and Wales at the end of their qualifying rounds.
In summary, Dominici is backing France to win the six-nation tournament, promising they can still achieve victory even if they lose one more game.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Dominici says France can still win the Six Nations Grand Slam despite recent poor performances against Scotland and England, citing their solid defence, efficient kicking game, and desire to play well to claim it.
Key match dates: France vs Wales (Stade de France, Feb 26), Ireland vs France (Dublin, Mar 12).
Dominici expects his team's future form will become clearer from the third matches.
qwen2.5:3b: Christophe Dominici of France suggests they can still win the Six Nations Grand Slam despite recent lacklustre performances against Scotland and England, attributing their chances to an efficient kicker like Dimitri Yachvili, solid defense, and players playing hard.
They face Wales on 26 February and Ireland in Dublin on 12 March.
Dominici believes France can still achieve something if they have these factors, though Bernard Laporte will announce the starting lineup for the Wales game next Tuesday.
Players like Jimmy Marlu, Serge Betsen, Imanol Harinordoquy, Yannick Jauzion, Aurelien Rougerie, and Julien Laharrague are available after injury.

Despite dominating in the first half, France struggled with the English players.
Captain Wing Dominici believes that if they can maintain their kicking game and rely on Dimitri Yachvili's strong form, France could win the Six Nations Grand Slam despite these losses.
The team will announce its starting line-up next Tuesday against Wales.

Key to their success, according to Dominici, is scrum-half Dimitri Yachvili's goalkicking efficiency, along with a solid defense and team spirit.
Injured players include winger Jimmy Marlu (out for the rest of the tournament due to a knee injury) and flanker Serge Betsen (doubtful with a thigh injury).
Number eight Imanol Harinordoquy has recovered from his shoulder injury, while centres Yannick Jauzion and winger Aurelien Rougerie have returned to the squad.
Julien Laharrague has been called up as a replacement for Pepito Elhorga.
